"Michael Schuerig" <michael@...> wrote:

> On Tuesday 22 February 2005 11:48, Johannes Link wrote:
>> Or you can just use the ANT-Task-Class programmatically; an easy to
>> use wrapper around org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.SQLExec can be
>> programmed in a few minutes.
>
> Hi Johannes,
>
> when I wrote the test decorator yesterday I actually looked at the Ant
> task and considered doing what you suggest. For the time being I went
> with the simplest thing that works, i.e., stuffing the script file's
> entire contents into Statement#execute().

A couple of the things you get from the Ant code that you don't get from 
passing the whole thing to Statement.execute() are:

- Ability to continue on error, even if one (or more) of the statements 
doesn't execute properly

- Ability to have comments in your script starting with "//" or "--"

- More flexibility with delimiters (EOL or ;)

- Good logging to let you know which statements had problems

- Control over when the commit happens

With the DDL files we have these things were enough to tip the boat against 
"rolling our own".  Rather than writing a wrapper around 
org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.SQLExec, we copied & modified the source (as I 
indicated in my message yesterday), so that we didn't have to include a 
bunch of ant jars in our test classpath.

Jeff Nielsen
Digital Focus
